description.narrative: SORUDA and FOKAPAWA consortium will: 1. Create COVID-19 pandemic awareness among 2000 South Sudanese refugees (70%) and host communities (30%) in Lamwo District by 31st July 2020. 2. Provide 1,500 vulnerable households with COVID-19 PPEs for enhanced preparedness and control in Lamwo District by 31st July 2020 1. EFSVL Outcomes 1.1 Increased awareness on COVID-19 pandemic transmission modesand symptoms in line with MoH guidelines and Presidential Directives. 2.1 The vulnerable households (women,girls, elders etc) supplied with PPEs for protection against COVID-19 1.1 Activities 1.1.1 Conduct risk mapping among the refugee and host-community surveillance level for extremely vulnerable households / PSN 1.1.2 Translate key COVID-19 messages in to local languages and sharing on local radios and social media (WhatsApp, etc.) 1.1.3 Run spot messages, songs and drama in Local Languages in local radiosguided by WHO / MoH guidelines 1.1.4 Print and distribute WHO / MoH advisories and public health information on COVID-19 in to preferred Languages for refugees 1.1.5 Establish call back centre for addressing misinformation, psycho-social support and referral of COVID-19 related issues 1.1.6 Participate in District Health Coordination Meetings / Task Force while maintaining physical distancingthrough Skype, WhatsApp and tel-conferencing 2.1 Activities 2.1.1 Procure PPEs (backpack sprayers, chlorine for disinfection, gloves etc) 2.1.2 Provide community hand washing tip-taps, soaps, sanitizers and water purification supplies to the refugees and host-communities 2.1.3 Establish chlorination bucket points for water hand-washing points 2.1.4 Monitor the use and adherence to COVID-19 guidelines provided by WHO / MoH

participating-org.narrative: SORUDA formerly Soroti Rural Development Agency, was initiated by a group of volunteers to address aftermath of challenges arising from civil and political conflict. Its focus was to target rural communities who were returning to their homes by addressing their livelihood and food security needs. Legally, it got registered in 2000 with Ministry of internal affairs NGO board registration No. S.5914/2928. Thereafter, because of the decentralisation policy, the mother Soroti was sub divided to form eight Districts and legally SORUDA had to rebrand to take its acronym as a name and renewed its operation country wide. Increasing SORUDA was able to develop policies among which is the gender policy that guides SORUDA#s delivery of services to target 50% femaleparticipation. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS Program/project coverage has increased and interventions taken closure to communities specifically priorities given to female headed households, girls and Persons with Special Needs (PSN). Out of the targeting, SORUDA hasbeen able to reach 25,000 (11,000 male and 14,000 Females) participating households covering areas of Teso, Lango, Karamoja and some parts of west Nile (Adjumani). Developed simple group savings and loan schemes for purposes of improving access to smallfinancial services that do not have collaterals Introduced disaster preparedness grain storage facilities using improved technologies such as use of super grain bags, plastic and metallic silos Strengthened production and productivity Established a community network to address challenges of women and girl child abuses through community surveillance system and District production departments for disasters 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE To promotesustainable rural development through community driveneradication initiatives, good governance and emancipation initiatives To carry out capacity building through training in group development, advisory services and research. # To contribute to reduction of poverty in the rural poor communities # To empower women and carry out advocacy and sensitization on Child rights # To promote environment conservation and management # To promote peace building and conflict resolution in East, North and West Nile regions SORUDA#s activities and programme competences are organized around four main thematic areas namely; 1) Support Livelihood interventions; 2) Human rights and Good Governance 3) Water, Sanitation and Hygiene promotion 4) Emergency response and Disaster Risk Reduction 5) HIV/AIDS advocacy onprevention SORUDA has intervened in the rural communities of Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile regions in Uganda with interventions targeting farmers, youth in and out of school, children, pregnant mothers, Persons Living with HIV/AIDS and displaced persons 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING SORUDA has intervened in communities displaces, refugees and has worked in Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile. SORUDA has worked in hard to reach areas targeting the rural underserved and poverty strickencommunities. SORUDA has worked with Local Government structures, religious and Cultural sectors and other CSOs. The named actors supported in community mobilisation, sensitization beneficiary identification, security provision and complementary support SORUDA has adequate human and logistic resources Community presence and existence Ability to quickly respond to emergency situations in the community.
